ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Power cycle analysis
I learned how to evaluate different power cycles.
Learned how to evaluate various thermodynamic systems
We learned how to analyze different kinds of systems (heat transfer, work, entropy).
I learned how to tackle very complicated questions related to energy and insights into how to understand the flow of energy.
Learned how to evaluate thermodynamic systems in idealized steady state situations. Learned about energy flow, enthalpy, entropy, and methods of energy transfer.
I learned about thermodynamic laws and cycles.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: straightforward

Strengths: Professor Cha 
Weaknesses: zoom office hours
Sometimes the pace of learning for the material is quite quick but the problem sets are helpful to reinforce learning.
Professor Cha is a really good lecturer. Her lectures are very organized and she also works out a lot of examples in class which is very helpful.
The lectures were hard to follow, I would have preferred more organized slides instead of handwritten notes.

I think that the course is taught very well. The homework assignments facilitate student learning very well. However, although the material on the exams was reflective of the problem sets and what we learned in class, there was very little time to complete the exams, leading to low scores due to not being able to finish rather than not knowing the material. The averages on the midterm and final were extremely low, but the class is curved to make up for it.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall the live lectures were good and I appreciated the handwritten notes because it made it easier to keep up
I like of idea of taking notes on zoom, but it was sometimes hard to see her notes because it was out of focus.
Zoom formatted class is an intrinsically terrible way to learn, so I cannot fault the Professor for being not very engaging nor extremely effective at teaching the course.

The online lectures as a combination of power point slides and live note taking recorded from a camera was an effective method for the course. Overall the course was geared very well for online learning.
I think that recorded lectures were helpful to make the class more flexible for students.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, good class but kind of hard.
Yes, Professor Cha is really great, just be prepared to put in the work.
This is a challenging course, but if you put the work into it, it's worth it.
It is a required course for engineering, but I would absolutely not have taken it if it was not required.
Yes. Judy is a great and very enthusiastic professor and the course is very helpful for practicing equation solving skills.
I would recommend taking this class to ABET mechanical engineering majors that have to take it.
Yeah

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live lectures were always recorded
Live lecture but also recorded.
Lectures were also recorded
NA
